title: Kids used by illegal migrant parents as 'to claim BENEFITS' must be adopted, judge says
text:
Kids used by illegal migrant parents as 'to claim BENEFITS' must be adopted, judge says Kids used by illegal migrant parents as 'to claim BENEFITS' must be adopted, judge says TWO children whose illegal migrant parents were accused of using them as “puppets” to claim benefits should be put up for adoption in Britain, a judge has ruled. PUBLISHED: 02:27,   03:00,   The hearing took place in the High Court's Family Division 
The family, of who are said have lived in Britain for around 13 years, were alerted to social services three years ago after social workers became aware the family had become destitute. 
Astonishingly, the father had previously threatened to jump off a bridge with the children unless the council provided a “new house and financial assistance to the level he sought”. Related articles Donald Trump hails Brexit as chance for Britain to 'TAKE BACK CONTROL' 
The twisted parents even “coached” one child to falsely accuse school staff and social workers of sexual abuse. 
The woman was ruled to have “overstayed” after arriving in Britain legitimately, while her husband has “no record” of ever entering the country. 
Social services staff had put the youngsters on a “child in need” plan and gave the family financial support. GETTY The father threatened to jump off a bridge with the children unless given welfare by the council 
But the couple started a “conflict” with social workers and believed their local council should provide “wholly” for the family. 
The children were used “directly to demand money” and shockingly hid in cupboards to stop social workers seeing them. 
Mr Justice Keehan said adoption would be in the “welfare best interest” of the children, aged seven and five, and would provide “stability, security and permanence”. GETTY The mother "overstayed" in the UK after legitimately arriving in the country 
The ruling came following a private hearing in the High Court’s Family Division in London. 
Justice Keehan did not identify the family by name, but indicated they had lived in Birmingham. 
The judge said both parents were of “south Indian origin” and had lived in Britain for around 13 years. GETTY Mr Justice Keehan ruled the children should be put up for adoption 
He added that social workers thought the youngsters had been “puppets” in a “war of attrition”. 
Justice Keehan also indicated the father was still in the UK but said the mother was living abroad. 2017: The Year Ahead
